#Text=Chapter Two : Master Lunre
#Text=My father ’s actions were largely incomprehensible to me , guided by his own secret and labyrinthine calculations .
#Text=He dwelt in another world , a world of intrigue , bargains , contracts and clandestine purchases of land all over the island .
#Text=He was in many ways a world in himself , whole as a sphere .
#Text=No doubt his decisions were perfectly logical in his own eyes — even the one that prompted him , a patriotic islander , to bring me a tutor from Bain : Master Lunre , an Olondrian .
#Text=The day began as it usually did when my father was expected home from his travels , the house festooned with flowers and stocked with coconut liquor .
#Text=We stood by the gate , washed and perfumed and arrayed in our brightest clothes , my mother twisting her hands in her skirt , my father ’s wife with red eyes .
#Text=Jom , grown taller and broad in the shoulders , moaned gently to himself , while I stood nervously rubbing the heel of one sandal on the flagstones .
#Text=We scanned the deep blue valley for the first sign of the company , but before we saw them we heard the children shouting : “ A yellow man ! ”
#Text=A yellow man !
#Text=We glanced at one another in confusion .
#Text=My mother bit her lower lip ; Jom gave a groan of alarm .

#Text=At first I thought the children meant my father , whose golden skin , the color of the night-monkey ’s pelt , was a rarity in the islands ; but certainly the children of Tyom were familiar with my father , and would never have greeted a council-member with such ill-mannered yells .

#Text=Then I remembered the only “ yellow man ” I had ever seen , an Olondrian wizard and doctor who had visited Tyom in my childhood , who wore two pieces of glass on his eyes , attached to his ears with wires , and roamed the hills of Tinimavet , cutting bits off the trees .

#Text=I have since learned that that doctor wrote a well-received treatise , On the Medicinal Properties of the Juice of the Young Coconut , and died a respected man in his native city of Deinivel ; but at the time I felt certain he had returned with his sack of tree-cuttings .
#Text=“ There they are , ” said Pavit , the head house-servant , in a strained voice .
#Text=And there they were : a chain of riders weaving among the trees .
#Text=My father ’s plaited umbrella appeared , his still , imposing figure , and beside him another man , tall and lean , astride an island mule .
#Text=The hectic screams of the children preceded the company into the village , so that they advanced like a festival , drawing people out of their houses .
#Text=As they approached I saw that my father ’s face was shining with pride , and his bearing had in it a new hauteur , like that of the old island kings .
#Text=The man who rode beside him , looking uncomfortable with his long legs , kept his gaze lowered and fixed between the ears of his plodding mule .
#Text=He was not yellow , but very pale brown , the color of raw cashews ; he had silver hair , worn cropped close to the skull so that it resembled a cap .
#Text=He was not the leaf-collecting doctor , but an altogether strange man , with silver eyebrows in his smooth face and long fine-knuckled hands .
#Text=As he dismounted in front of the house I heard my mother whispering : “ Protect us , God with the Black-and-White Tail , from that which is not of this earth . ”
#Text=My father dismounted from his mule and strutted toward us , grinning .
#Text=I thought I caught an odor off him , of fish , sea-sickness and sweat .
#Text=We knelt and stared down at the bald ground , murmuring ritual greetings , until he touched the tops of our heads with the palm of his fleshy hand .
#Text=Then we stood , unable to keep from staring at the stranger , who faced us awkwardly , half-smiling , taller than any man there .
